segments.text: For several months, Leora came almost every weekend to stay in the room she chose for herself in her pink house.
Besides Danny the vet, sometimes another tenant or two would come for the night, and on Thursdays, sometimes also for dinner and breakfast the next day.
But most of the time, she was there alone, hidden from everyone, cleaning and cooking a little for herself, and mainly absorbed in reading books she borrowed from Russia, her friend from the army.
The previous weekend, she had to stay on base, but now she was on her way home for a long weekend.
No one knew yet, not in the army and not even Yosef.
She felt ashamed of being a refugee relying on Yehuda's kindness and didn't want to be looked at with pity.
In everyone's eyes, she was strong and successful, and no one knew the heartbreak that was tied to leaving this house.
She even asked Carmella, the neighbor, not to say anything to anyone.
I don't know how long this will last, so there should be nothing for people to talk about."
Carmela looked at her seriously.
You know, you need to be checked, she said.
It's unclear how you turned out so normal with everything you've been through.
They both smiled.
She felt her heart lift as she got on the bus knowing she was on her way home, hoping nothing in the garden had withered since it hadn't been watered for nearly two weeks.
The stop for the pink house.
She heard duty the driver announce in a particularly festive voice for her.
She waved him goodbye and got off the bus happily.
After a few steps, she heard the sprinklers rattling throughout the garden and wondered who had turned them on.
She joyfully opened the front door and stood rooted to the spot, mouth open and eyes staring blankly, unable to believe what she saw.
Within moments, the tears that welled up in her eyes trickled down her cheeks uncontrollably for the first time since Lucy passed away.
The piano stood in the open space it had been taken from.
Her piano, a large note with a drawing of a red rose, was lying on the lid, with handwriting that was so familiar to her.
It's not your home without a piano.
Love you very much, dad."
The bag dropped at her feet.
She pulled a chair up to the piano, sat on it.
Lifted the lid and discovered a green felt piece above the keys.
She unfolded it gently and carefully placed her fingers on the keys, barely breathing.
Pretend you're happy when you're blue.
It isn't very hard to do, and you'll find happiness without an end whenever you pretend.
All this time the tears flowed and without realizing it turned into a sobbing cry.
She cried over the piano, over all the other things taken from her that she had to give up.
And now slowly they were returning.
Even in such a happy moment her floodgates opened.
Inside she was shaken.
Why hadn't I cried for mom out of all this pain?
How did these tears, which always stopped at the edge of my eyes and refused to spill over, manage to find their way out just now because of the piano?
She remained sitting quietly, wiping her eyes with the back of her hand, refusing to part from the chair in front of the beloved keys.
She wondered how Yosa found out she was staying there.
She was supposed to tell him and hadn't found the courage for it.
He should have heard it from her.
It almost slipped out at Jackie's café, but the conversation there veered into such a loaded topic, and she didn't want to add to it.
Now she felt remorse, but at the same time, she felt great relief that her secret was out.
She would call him in the evening, apologize, explain, say thank you.
She also thought, out of all the songs, why this one?
It's so perfectly captured what was happening in her life.
She knew she was pretending, pretending to be happy when she was sad, that everything was okay, that nothing had happened.
She knew it was just an act.
But here, within all this pretense, small moments of happiness arrived.
